ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I thoroughly enjoyed this course and would highly recommend it to other students. It provided a great opportunity to branch out and explore the humanities side of forestry.

Interesting instructor with a lot to offer. His analyses and discussions of antiquities and the storiesbehind them were fascinating.The course needs more structure to improve learning. Adhering to a reading list and having topics for each field trip would have been extremely helpful for stimulating discussion. It felt like the lectures were off the cuff. Many times I was just wandering around the museums, with no real objective.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: A lot of time and space for own thoughts.
Paul's lectures in the Beineke Library
The field trips and Professor Draghi's commentary really enhanced this course.

Access to the excellent museums and galleries we visited. Rare and unique artifacts.Dr. Draghi's knowledge and experiences. He is a good storyteller, with lots to offer a class.The option to pursue a final project on whatever you'd like.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The readings.
More integrated reading into lectures and field trips
Perhaps a bit more structure in terms of discussion and readings might have improved this course.

It needs far more structure. We weren't really encouraged to do the readings, which made for a random feeling orientation to the course at times. I think just identifying a topic to study or think about each week would have done a lot to direct our efforts.It seemed like the TA did very little. He was supposed to schedule a final presentation day, which he didn't. This was disappointing, as I had prepared for a presentation, but then never got to give it. Also, he was supposed to show several videos, which also never happened. I feel like he could have accomplished his objectives in an hour of his time, tops, but it just never happened.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The lectures were informal and didn't always tie back to themes that we could identify. I think with more structure the course could vastly be improved. All the elements are there: interesting instructor, great museums and galleries, etc. We just needed far more structure and higher expectations out of the students.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I was looking for a class that gave me a vantage point into human psychology in relationship to natural resources and the natural environment. This class, more or less, fit that role.
This course contributed to the fulfilling the humanities requirements of my major.

For people from science backgrounds, the course brings a fresh breath of creativity, art, myth and religion and how apart from the modern sciences, they are also effective means of capturing and passing on wisdom and knowledge about the environment around us.
It is not directly related to my overall program, though I was able to complete a final project that is somewhat related to my studies at F&ES.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interest in topic.
I took this course to broaden my understanding of the liberal and humanities aspects of forestry and environmental studies.

It looked interesting; the class got good feedback from a fellow student; Dr. Draghi is an interesting instructor with great knowledge of history and Yale; the readings looked really fascinating (though we never ended up doing them or following the syllabus)

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Hardly... I wish the course had been more like outlined in the syllabus.

Not completely. I'm not sure that I can speak very clearly on how archetypical forms really drive our relationship with the natural world. This is a connection, perhaps, I will have to make on my own.
Yes, I feel like I learned a lot about the relationship between humanity and nature.

Not quite. I did learn some, but I expected much more. I think the lack of structure really hurt my chances of getting a lot out of the course. It seemed like we were just rolling from field trip to field trip with no clear goals at times.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: For the well motivated: select your own readings and do them. Take the final project as an opportunity to try something you have always wanted to do, but never had the space to do it in.
Go into this course with an open mind and you will have a wonderful time!

The three hour long trips require patience on the part of those uninitiated to the arts, but over time one leans to slow down and appreciate subtleties and fineness. The classes will definitely make a difference, albeit one that will only become more obvious in the long term.

This is a good course to balance an otherwise challenging work load. I had a difficult term otherwise, and appreciated the time each week to learn on field trips at museums and galleries. I also like the instructor and enjoyed his guidance on the field trips. The antiquities we saw and interacted with were fascinating.I wouldn't expect to learn a ton about archetypes, though perhaps with some initiative you could read the books that were on the syllabus (not followed) and get more out of the course. The instructor was available to speak with, and I think with initiative you could interact with him on an individual basis and gain more. Overall, the opportunity to learn a lot was there, but the course wasn't very rigorous and didn't quite meet expectations.
